item.title: Monsoons Bring Flash Food Watches for Arizona and New Mexico
item.description: The Southwest’s wet season will help provide relief for a yearlong drought.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Heyward
item.media:credit: Jake Bacon/Arizona Daily Sun, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Monsoon rains led to flooding near Flagstaff, Ariz., last week.

item.title: How Mormon Women Are Having Frank Talks About Sacred Underclothes
item.description: Frustrated by itchy, constrictive church-designed garments, they are asking for better fit, more options and “buttery soft fabric.”
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sasha Piton, 33, has called on the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints to manufacture more breathable and comfortable temple garments for its members.

item.title: U.S. Life Expectancy Plunged in 2020, Especially for Black and Hispanic Americans
item.description: The 18-month drop, the steepest decline since World War II, was fueled by the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman, Sophie Kasakove and Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: A coronavirus testing site in San Bernardino, Calif., in December. The difficult year deepened racial and ethnic disparities in life expectancy, with Black and Hispanic Americans losing nearly two more years than white Americans.

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Cuba for Crackdowns on Protesters
item.description: Among those facing the human rights sanctions are Cuba’s defense minister and special forces troops who swept up protesters in a wave of arrests larger than any other crackdown over the last few years, if not decades.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:credit: Yamil Lage/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A man was arrested during a demonstration against the government of Cuban President Miguel Díaz-Canel in Havana, earlier this month.

item.title: Abby Finkenauer Challenges Grassley for Iowa Senate Seat
item.description: Abby Finkenauer, a 32-year-old former congresswoman, is jumping into next year’s race against Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Republican incumbent.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Kathryn Gamble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former congresswoman Abby Finkenauer in Cedar Rapids in 2018. Ms. Finkenauer lost her seat in 2020 after serving a single term representing the eastern part of Iowa.

item.title: C.D.C. Director Warns U.S. at ‘Another Pivotal Point’ in Pandemic
item.description: Still, new cases, hospitalizations and deaths remain at a fraction from their previous devastating peaks, and vaccines remain effective against the worst outcomes of Covid-19 including from the Delta variant.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Rochelle Walensky, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, again urged people on Thursday to take the Delta variant seriously by getting vaccinated.

item.title: House Republicans Use Vaccine Press Conference to Bash Democrats
item.description: The increased spread of the virus has prompted the G.O.P. to change its tone and confront the reluctance among its constituents to take the Covid-19 vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: House Minority Whip Steve Scalise insisted Republican messaging around coronavirus vaccines would not change at a press conference outside the U.S. Capitol on Thursday.

item.title: Details on F.B.I. Inquiry Into Kavanaugh Draw Fire From Democrats
item.description: The F.B.I. said some of the 4,500 tips it received about Justice Brett Kavanaugh were given to the Trump White House, leading some Democrats to call the process a sham.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of Democratic senators is pressing the F.B.I. for more information about how it worked with the Trump White House on the background investigations into Brett Kavanaugh before his Supreme Court confirmation.

item.title: Senate Panel Splits on Confirming Stone-Manning to Lead Land Agency
item.description: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic majority leader, is expected to advance Tracy Stone-Manning’s nomination. Democrats say they have the votes to confirm her.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Alex Brandon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tracy Stone-Manning at a confirmation hearing in Washington last month. Democrats believe they have the votes to confirm her to lead the Bureau of Land Management despite Republican opposition.

item.title: House to Vote to Allow More Afghans Interpreters to Immigrate to the U.S.
item.description: The legislation, spearheaded by Representative Jason Crow, Democrat of Colorado and a former Army Ranger, passed by a vote of 407 to 16.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Jason Crow, a former Army Ranger, spearheaded legislation that would expand the number of visas available to Afghans who helped the U.S. military during the 20-year war.

item.title: L.A. County’s Public Health Chief Discusses the Mask Mandate
item.description: Thursday: A conversation with Barbara Ferrer about how Los Angeles County is grappling with the Delta variant.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shopping in Santa Monica during the first day of the new mask mandate.

item.title: Wyden Delays Hearing on Biden's Nominee to Lead Customs and Border Protection
item.description: Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon is delaying a hearing until the administration answers questions about the response to last year’s unrest in Portland.
item.dc:creator: Eileen Sullivan
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Federal agents outside a courthouse in Portland, Ore., last July during clashes with protesters.

item.title: Jerry Lewis, Master of the Congressional Earmark, Dies at 86
item.description: A powerful legislator, he became chairman of the House Appropriations Committee in 2005 but faced scrutiny from the Justice Department for his ties to a lobbyist.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Gerald Herbert/Associated Press
item.media:description: Representative Jerry Lewis, Republican of California, in his office in 2005, the year he became chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

item.title: A Grizzly Bear Terrorized a Man for Days in Alaska. The Coast Guard Saw His SOS.
item.description: Down to his last rounds of ammunition, with bruises and a leg injury, the man was rescued by a helicopter crew that just happened by.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: F.T.C. Votes to Back Right-to-Repair Rules
item.description: An advocacy group for technology companies criticized the move by the commission, saying it would jeopardize the safety of consumers.
item.dc:creator: Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Regis Duvignau/Reuters
item.media:description: A worker refurbishes a cell phone.

item.title: Trust in Fauci and U.S. Health Agencies Resilient in a New Study
item.description: A majority of Americans believes in guidance from the C.D.C., the F.D.A. and Dr. Fauci, despite misinformation and frequent criticisms.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, addresses a Senate committee hearing on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Says Nixing Filibuster Would Throw Congress ‘Into Chaos’
item.description: “I don’t want the debate to only be about whether or not we have a filibuster,” the president said at a CNN town hall.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden participates in a town hall hosted by CNN’s Don Lemon at Mount St. Joseph University in Cincinnati, on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden predicts the F.D.A. will give final approval to a Covid vaccine by the fall.
item.description: The president also said he expected children under the age of 12 would be approved to get the vaccine on an emergency basis “soon.”
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland and Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Sarahbeth Maney/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden participated in a town hall hosted by CNN’s Don Lemon at Mount St. Joseph’s University in Cincinnati on Wednesday.

item.title: Why Jim Banks and Jim Jordan Were Blocked From the Capitol Riot Panel
item.description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said she was barring them from a committee scrutinizing the attack based on Democrats’ concerns about their “statements made and actions taken” around the assault.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kevin McCarthy, left, the House minority leader, on Wednesday with three representatives he had picked for a select committee to investigate the riot at the Capitol: Kelly Armstrong, Jim Jordan and Jim Banks.

item.title: G.O.P. Blocks Infrastructure Debate in Senate, Raising Doubts About a Deal
item.description: The failed test vote reflected mistrust between Democrats and Republicans, raising questions about whether they could agree on a key piece of President Biden’s agenda.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio, is one of the leaders of a bipartisan group attempting to negotiate an infrastructure deal.

item.title: Pelosi Bars Trump Loyalists From Jan. 6 Inquiry, Prompting a G.O.P. Boycott
item.description: Democrats said Representatives Jim Banks and Jim Jordan, who amplified Donald J. Trump’s lies of a stolen election and opposed investigating the assault, could not be trusted to scrutinize it.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi said that she was rejecting the appointments of Representatives Jim Jordan of Ohio, left, and Jim Banks of Indiana based on their actions around the riot and comments they had made undercutting the investigation.

item.title: U.S. Rushes to Evacuate Afghan Translators But Leaves Many in Limbo
item.description: This month, 2,500 Afghans will be sent in stages to an Army base in Fort Lee, Va.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sayed Obaidullah Amin, who interpreted for the U.S. Marine Corps for two years, was denied a visa to the United States. He said this year that he believed it was because he once returned to duty late from a leave to deal with his father’s heart attack.

item.title: Battle for Power in Haiti Extends to Lobbying in Washington
item.description: Rival political figures and interests are doling out big sums to the influence industry to win support from the United States even as problems in Haiti remain unsolved.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Haitian government had been ramping up its spending on Washington lobbying in the months before the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse.

item.title: ‘Incel’ Is Charged With Plotting to Shoot Women, U.S. Says
item.description: Tres Genco, 21, of Hillsboro, Ohio, was charged with an attempted hate crime and illegally possessing a machine gun, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Justice building in Washington. A federal grand jury has indicted an Ohio man on charges that he plotted to shoot students in sororities.

item.title: In Deal With Germany, U.S. Drops Threat to Block Russian Gas Pipelines
item.description: The agreement infuriated both Republicans and Democrats in Congress, who accused the Biden administration of being soft on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Anton Vaganov/Reuters
item.media:description: The construction site of the Nord Stream 2 project, near the town of Kingisepp, Russia, in 2019.

item.title: Spanish Olympian Disappointed to Leave Breastfeeding Son at Home
item.description: Carbonell, competing in her third Games, said in an Instagram video that she had been made to choose between her family and her Olympic goal.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Clive Rose/Getty Images
item.media:description: Ona Carbonell competing in Gwangju, South Korea, at the world championships in 2019.

item.title: Judge Temporarily Blocks Arkansas Ban on Health Treatments for Transgender Youth
item.description: The decision came in response to an American Civil Liberties Union challenge to a first-in-the-nation law enacted by Republican state legislators in April.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.category: Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation
item.media:credit: Andrea Morales/Getty Images

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Accepting the virus.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Red Tide Piles Up Dead Fish on Florida Beaches
item.description: “This,” proclaimed an editorial in The Tampa Bay Times last week, “is what climate change smells like.”
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Djinis
item.media:credit: Arielle Bader/Tampa Bay Times, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Dead fish from a red tide washed up along a waterfront park in St. Petersburg, Fla., this month.

item.title: ‘Complete Taliban Takeover’ Possible Outcome for Afghanistan, General Milley Says
item.description: The comments by Gen. Mark A. Milley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, echoed mounting reports from the ground in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Paula Bronstein/Getty Images
item.media:description: An Afghan security officer stands guard outside a mosque in Kabul on Tuesday.
